pageProps.body:
Exam 1 Prep

(click "Go to text" for more information or see the corresponding section in the book available on Pearson)

[6.1] Velocity, Position, and Displacement

Velocity

Position

From Displacement
Go to text →

Finding the displacement

To find the displacement of an object, we do not need to know its initial position. Whether an object moves from s=−20s=-20s=−20 to s=−10s=-10s=−10 or from s=50s=50s=50 to s=60s=60s=60 makes no difference- the displacement is 10 units.

From Position
Go to text →

Finding the future position

Suppose we know the velocity of an object and its initial position (s(0)s(0)s(0)). The goal is to find the position s(t)s(t)s(t) for t>0t>0t>0. The Fundamental Theorem gives us the answer directly. Because the position sss is an antiderivative of the velocity vvv, we have

∫0tv(x)dx=∫0ts′(x)dx=s(t)−s(0)\int^t_0{v(x)}{dx}=\int^t_0{s\prime(x)}{dx}=s(t)-s(0)∫0t​v(x)dx=∫0t​s′(x)dx=s(t)−s(0)

From Acceleration
Go to text →

Velocity from Acceleration

Given the acceleration a(t)a(t)a(t) of an object moving along a line and its initial velocity v(0)v(0)v(0), the velocity of the object for future times t≥0t\geq0t≥0 is

v(t)=v(0)+∫0ta(x)dx.v(t)=v(0)+\int_0^t{a(x)}{dx}\text{.}v(t)=v(0)+∫0t​a(x)dx.

This is a consequence of the Fundamental Theorem.

From Net Change and Future Value
Go to text →

Net change and future value

Suppose a quantity QQQ changes over time at a known rate Q′Q\primeQ′. Then the net change in QQQ between t=at=at=a and t=b>at=b>at=b>a is

∫0tQ′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}=Q(t)-Q(0)∫0t​Q′(x)dx=Q(t)−Q(0)

Given the initial value Q(0)Q(0)Q(0), the future value of QQQ at time t≥0t\geq0t≥0 is

Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0tQ′(x)dxQ(t)=Q(0)+\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0t​Q′(x)dx

Correspondences between velocity-displacement problems and more general problems:

Velocity-Displacement ProblemsGeneral Problems
Position s(t)s(t)s(t)Quantity Q(t)Q(t)Q(t) (such as volume or population size)
Velocity: s′(t)=v(t)s\prime(t)=v(t)s′(t)=v(t)Rate of change: Q′(t)Q\prime(t)Q′(t)
Displacement: s(b)−s(a)=∫abv(t)dts(b)-s(a)=\int_a^b{v(t)}{dt}s(b)−s(a)=∫ab​v(t)dtNet change: Q(b)−Q(a)=∫abQ′(t)dtQ(b)-Q(a)=\int_a^b{Q\prime(t)}{dt}Q(b)−Q(a)=∫ab​Q′(t)dt
Future Position: s(t)=s(0)+∫0tv(x)dxs(t)=s(0)+\int_0^t{v(x)}{dx}s(t)=s(0)+∫0t​v(x)dxFuture value of QQQ: Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0tQ′(x)dxQ(t)=Q(0)+\int_0^t{Q\prime(x)}{dx}Q(t)=Q(0)+∫0t​Q′(x)dx

[6.2] Regions between curves

From Regions between Curves
Go to text →

Area of a region between two curves

Suppose that fff and ggg are continuous functions with f(x)≥g(x)f(x)\geq g(x)f(x)≥g(x) on the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b]. The are of the region bounded by the graphs of fff and ggg on [a,b][a,b][a,b] is

A=∫ab(f(x)−g(x))dx.A=\int_a^b{(f(x)-g(x))}{dx}\text{.}A=∫ab​(f(x)−g(x))dx.

Area of a region between two curves with respect to yyy

There are some cases where the area between two curves needs to be found on the yyy axis.

Suppose that fff and ggg are continuous functions with f(y)≥g(y)f(y)\geq g(y)f(y)≥g(y) on the interval [c,d][c,d][c,d]. The area of the region bounded by the graphs x=f(y)x=f(y)x=f(y) and x=g(x)x=g(x)x=g(x) on [c,d][c,d][c,d] is

A=∫xd(f(y)−g(y))dy.A=\int_x^d{(f(y)-g(y))}{dy}\text{.}A=∫xd​(f(y)−g(y))dy.

[6.3] Volume by slicing

Methods

  • General Slicing Method
  • Disk Method
  • Washer Method

[6.4] Volume by shells

From Shell Method
Go to text →

Definition

Let fff and ggg be continuous functions with f(x)≥g(x)f(x)\geq g(x)f(x)≥g(x) on [a,b][a,b][a,b]. If RRR is the region bounded by the curves y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x) and y=g(x)y=g(x)y=g(x) between the lines x=ax=ax=a and x=bx=bx=b, the volume of the solid generated when RRR is revolved about the y-axis is

V=∫ab2πx(f(x)−g(x))dx.V=\int_a^b{2\pi x(f(x)-g(x))}{dx}\text.V=∫ab​2πx(f(x)−g(x))dx.

[6.5] Length of curves

From Arc Length
Go to text →

Definition for y=f(x)y=f(x)y=f(x)

Let fff have a continuous first derivative on the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b]. The length of the curve from (a,f(a))(a,f(a))(a,f(a)) to (b,f(b))(b,f(b))(b,f(b)) is

L=∫abq+f′(x)2dx.L=\int_a^b{\sqrt{q+f\prime(x)^2}}{dx}\text.L=∫ab​q+f′(x)2​dx.

Definition for x=g(y)x=g(y)x=g(y)

Let x=g(y)x=g(y)x=g(y) have a continuous first derivative on the interval [c,d][c,d][c,d]. The length of the curve from (g(c),c)(g(c), c)(g(c),c) to (g(d),d)(g(d), d)(g(d),d) is

L=∫xd1+g′(y)2dy.L=\int_x^d{\sqrt{1+g\prime(y)^2}}{dy}\text.L=∫xd​1+g′(y)2​dy.

[6.6] Surface area

From Surface Area
Go to text →

Definition

Let fff be differentiable and positive on the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b]. The area of the surface generated when the graph of fff on the interval [a,b][a,b][a,b] is revolved about the xxx-axis is

S=∫ab2πf(x)1+f′(x)2dx.S=\int_a^b{2\pi f(x)\sqrt{1+f\prime(x)^2}}{dx}\text.S=∫ab​2πf(x)1+f′(x)2​dx.

Surface area of a spherical zone

S=∫ab2πf(x)1+f′(x)2dxS=\int_a^b{2\pi f(x)\sqrt{1+f\prime(x)^2}}{dx}S=∫ab​2πf(x)1+f′(x)2​dx

(after substituting and simplifying...)

=2π∫0hadx=2\pi\int_0^h{a}{dx}=2π∫0h​adx

[6.7] Physical applications

From Mass
Go to text →

Mass = Density * Volume

Mass of a one-dimensional object

Suppose a thin bar or wire is represented by the interval a≤x≤ba\leq x\leq ba≤x≤b with a density function ρ\rhoρ (that's called "rho" apparently) (with units of mass per length). The mass of the object is

m=∫abρ(x)dx.m=\int_a^b{\rho(x)}{dx}\text.m=∫ab​ρ(x)dx.

From Work
Go to text →

Definition

The work done by a variable force FFF in moving an object along a line from x=ax=ax=a to x=bx=bx=b in the direction of the force is

W=∫abF(x)dx.W=\int_a^b{F(x)}{dx}\text.W=∫ab​F(x)dx.

Lifting problems

The work required to lift this chain is

W=∫0Lρg(L−y)dyW=\int_0^L{\rho g(L-y)}{dy}W=∫0L​ρg(L−y)dy

LLL is the distance to be lifted, ρ\rhoρ is the Mass of the object, and ggg represents gravity.

(ggg being gravity is almost always 9.89.89.8)

Pumping problems

Suppose a fluid such as water is pumped out of a tank to a height hhh above the bottom of the tank. How much work is required, assuming the tank is full of water?

Procedure

  1. Draw a yyy-axis in the vertical direction
  2. For a≤y≤ba\leq y\leq ba≤y≤b, find the cross-sectional area A(y)A(y)A(y) of the horizontal slices and the distance D(y)D(y)D(y) the slices must be lifted
  3. The work required to lift the water is
    W=∫abρgA(y)D(y)dy.W=\int_a^b{\rho gA(y)D(y)}{dy}\text.W=∫ab​ρgA(y)D(y)dy.

Example

The resulting integral is

W=∫010ρgA(y)D(y)dyW=\int_0^{10}{\rho gA(y)D(y)}{dy}W=∫010​ρgA(y)D(y)dy
A(y)=πr2=π52=25πA(y)=\pi r^2=\pi 5^2=25\piA(y)=πr2=π52=25π
D(y)=15−yD(y)=15-yD(y)=15−y
W=∫010ρ∗(9.8)∗(25π)(15−y)∗dyW=\int_0^{10}{\rho*(9.8)*(25\pi)(15-y)*}{dy}W=∫010​ρ∗(9.8)∗(25π)(15−y)∗dy
=25πρ(9.8)∫010(15−y)dy=25\pi\rho(9.8)\int_0^{10}{(15-y)}{dy}=25πρ(9.8)∫010​(15−y)dy

From Force and Pressure
Go to text →

Pressure is a force per unit area.

F=mass∗acceleration=volume∗density∗g=AhρgF=\text{mass}*\text{acceleration}=\text{volume}*\text{density}*g=Ah\rho gF=mass∗acceleration=volume∗density∗g=Ahρg

, where ρ\rhoρ is the density of the water, and ggg is acceleration due to gravity.

Force-on-dam problem

  1. Draw a y-axis on the face of the dam in the vertical direction and choose a convenient origin (usually the base)
  2. Find the width function w(y)w(y)w(y) for each value of yyy on the face of the dam
  3. If the base of the dam is at y=0y=0y=0 and the top of the dam is at y=ay=ay=a, then the total force on the dam is
    F=∫0aρg(a−y)w(y)dy.F=\int_0^a{\rho g(a-y)w(y)}{dy}\text.F=∫0a​ρg(a−y)w(y)dy.
